author: Sean Martin
title: RPI football runs over Rochester
text:
RPI football runs over Rochester 1 / 4 Back to Gallery 
Troy 
With Rochester facing a fourth-and-one at its own 29-yard line early in the fourth quarter, the Yellowjackets were either trying to draw RPI into an offsides penalty or going all in with a bold decision against the Engineer defense in a 21-21 game. 
RPI junior linebacker Alexander Greenlidge was ready and when Rochester tried an inside handoff in the game's defining moment, Greenlidge and his teammates were more than ready to seize the momentum by stopping Myles Allen short of the first down. 
Following the stop, the Engineers used the short field to take the lead for good before adding an insurance touchdown for a gritty 35-21 win over Rochester to keep alive their hopes for a Liberty League title. 
"Going for it that deep in their territory, it (trying to draw RPI offside) is always in the back of your head but we were ready when they snapped the ball to fire out," Greenlidge said. "We beat them to the trenches there, I'm thinking straight up the gut and I jumped it, stone him, build a wall, and push them back." 
Following the turnover on downs, RPI cashed in four plays later when Mike Tivinis scored on a six-yard run to go up 28-21 with 12:01 left in the fourth. 
In a matchup featuring two of the three highest scoring teams in the league. RPI relied on its running game that accounted for 239 yards on 53 carries, including Nick Schlatz 's two-yard run with 4:20 left to give the Engineers a 35-21 lead. 
RPI (5-2, 3-1 Liberty League) is a half-game behind St. Lawrence (5-1, 3-0) in the conference standings with three games to play, although St. Lawrence holds the tiebreaker advantage with its 24-21 win over RPI last week. 
RPI rushed for just 50 yards in the loss to St. Lawrence and came into the Rochester game intent on establishing its ground game, which it did, holding the ball for 35:34. It kept the Yellowjackets' offense, which came in averaging just less than 32 points per game, off the field. 
"Anytime you are able to move a man against his will, that is what running the football is," RPI coach Ralph Isernia said. "The yardage really wears down a defense and it wears you down psychologically as well because there is not a whole lot you can do about it." 
RPI took a 14-7 halftime lead, keyed by an 84-yard kickoff return for a touchdown by Johnny Ramsdell . The Engineers had three interceptions, two by Phil Lanieri III and another by Greenlidge, and opened the second half with a 15-play, 94-yard drive that was capped by Matt Lane 's two-yard touchdown run. 
Thirteen plays on the drive were rushes, including nine by Schlatz, who finished with a team-high 116 yards on 27 carries and two touchdowns. 
"We're a ground-it-out type of team," Schlatz said. "Today we found what was working and we stuck with it. The linemen on this team are my best friends, they do their job and I do mine. When you get 13 runs on a drive, everyone is doing their job." 
RPI was especially effective on third downs, converting 11 of 20 chances. It ran 86 plays on offense compared to 71 for Rochester (4-2, 2-2). 
Sean Martin , a local freelance writer, is a frequent contributor to the Times Union . Most Popular
